Description: Body sherd of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black with narrow added white and red bands; exterior: boar (part of body with red dots and mane remaining) possibly to right.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos describes the sherd as coming from a mediocre, but big chalice belonging to the Group of Elaborate Animal Chalices. Chalices that fall into this group are usually large and heavy-walled and are also known as chalice-kraters. Chalices in this group display elaborate compositions that include polychromy and delicately painted figures (Lemos 1991, 90-1).
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 90, p. 264, no. 559, pl. 71)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 82, no. 20. pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0633) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
